headline: President Trump fights back against congressional Democrats' subpoena demands
subHeadline: Trump rips Democrats' post-Mueller agenda as Dems threaten impeachment; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Dana Perino, and Greg. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” President Trump is ready for all-out war with investigation crazed Democrats on Capitol Hill.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: And I have been the most transparent president and administration in the history of our country by far. Now, the House goes and starts subpoenaing. They want to know every deal I've ever done. Now, Mueller, I assume, for $35 million, checked my taxes, checked my financials which are greats, but we're fighting all the subpoenas.  Look, these aren't like impartial people. The Democrats are trying to win 2020, but they be should really focused on legislation. If you want to litigate, go after the DNC, crooked Hillary, the dirty cops.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Trump's fighting back against an avalanche of Democratic subpoenas including one calling for former White House Counsel Don McGahn to testify about the Mueller report. Trump's also saying that if Democrats do decide to impeach him he'll fight it all the way to the Supreme Court. Democrats responding by ramping up their rhetoric. Here's Nancy Pelosi.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: It's not about politics. It's about patriotism. It's an existential threat, this administration, to our democracy in terms of our constitution. I do believe that impeachment is one of the most divisive forces of paths that we could go down to our country, but if the facts -- the path of fact-finding takes us there, we have no choice. But we're not there yet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And Maxine Waters who's been screaming about impeachment for two years is as unhinged as ever.

utterances.speaker: REP. MAXINE WATERS, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: I know that, as leaders, they have the responsibility to try and hold our caucus together. And to try and do and lead in the best way that they think will help us to be successful. If they believe that now was not the time for impeachment, they'll keep trying and they'll go down that road. We're going to have to impeach. I just wish it was sooner than later.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. Well, we know what Maxine thinks, Greg. Nancy, I mean, she's the leader of the party in the House and she says that this administration is an existential threat to our democracy.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: That's crazy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What does that even mean?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's a very overused term, existential. An existential threat, asteroids, cataclysmic climate change, Islamic terror, any time you're stuck in an elevator and Maroon 5 is playing, existential threat, but this is not. The suggestion that you are not a patriot if you somehow disagree with this idea, if you don't join in the resistance, we talked about this before, the expanding target of denigration, you are not a patriot.  Let's go back to 2015, 2016. Having concerns about Trump made total sense, right? I had so many concerns. He wasn't a politician. His personality, he was a bull in a China shop. He never knew what he was going to do. He had an interesting, colorful past. And plus, you had all these other options. You have good options in the Republican Party. You had safer options. It didn't turn out that way but concerns made common sense. Now, people are having the same concerns three years later. None of their fears have materialized. The world -- he has not started any new wars. In fact, he has tried to shrink our military footprint. He has not destroyed the economy. We have a booming economy. We have the lowest unemployment in modern history. He's help minorities and women in that world.  So when you see this kind of panic going on, all you can think about is it's OK if you're a Democrat. I get it. It's team sports. That's what you do. But if you actually believe this stuff, I would say like a never- Trump Republican, it's emotional and it's irrational. It's stupid. And that's all I've got to say.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, where do you think the Democrats stand right now on impeachment? It looks like they're pretty split, but no one can actually name the crime that they're impeaching him for. We're talking about broad things like a threat to democracy. That's not going to stick.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: That's not what we're talking about.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What are we talking about?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm alarmed that you don't realize that--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What is the crime?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- we're talking about obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But how did he do that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, gosh, he tried to tell Don McGahn --this is the point of great concern right now. He told McGahn to fire Mueller --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So he didn't Mueller.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. McGahn, apparently, disobeyed his order. Now, Trump says nobody disobeyed his order, but we've seen --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wanting to fire someone which he has every right to do under article two. Wanting to fire someone is obstruction of justice?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, wanting to stop this investigation. This is something that I hear sometimes --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He ordered -- he calls up his lawyer, Don McGahn, and tells him to have the attorney general fire Mueller because of conflict of interest when there was no such thing going on, and McGahn saves him because it would have been an absolute fiasco.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But how is he obstructing?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, let me just say, I mean, even the Wall Street Journal this morning just said, you know, they believed McGahn. Now, Trump is saying McGahn is not telling the truth. They say, you know what, Trump lies just so much and it undermines his own credibility in so many ways. That's the Wall Street Journal conserve editorial page this morning.  But let me just say there's so many instances like this. Greg says, oh, you know, things are going so great. Forget about normal Republican positions on things like lowering the deficit or not having all these trade tariffs or not undermining democracy --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How's the country going so far, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think that's going so well.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You don't have any evidence to counter.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You also say, Greg, oh, he's the most transparent president ever. If he's so transparent, why is he trying to stop Don McGahn from testifying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because enough is enough. He has given 1.4 million documents. Everyone has testified. He delivered written answered. Mueller looked at his taxes. There's nothing there. Why are the Democrats continuing to push this issue when they know that Mueller saw everything he needed to see?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All you can do is shout because he wouldn't even talk to Mueller. He did not testify for Mueller --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Written responses, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The point right now is that the Democrats are going to subpoena so much information -- I guess they could hold McGahn in, you know, contempt of Congress -- use to testify. But what the president and the White House are doing is basically slow walking it and saying, you know, we're stonewall, we'll slow walk, we'll end up in the courts, but we will not cooperate --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Emily, they've already cooperated fully. Mueller actually said that they have full cooperation. And right now, these two people, McGahn, Trump, special counsel, they're all under the executive branch. I mean, there's no reason they can't just claim executive privilege and say --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But they didn't claim it earlier.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They can claim it whenever they want.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, they can't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Watch.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because he didn't say that -- when it was about McGahn testifying --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm just saying it's obvious.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Here's what the president has on his side if he claims executive privilege for himself or McGahn moving forward, time and enforcement. What I mean by that is that subpoenas and orders of contempt are being held in contempt expires with that congressional duration, exactly.  So all the president has to do is get to January of 2021. And also it is the courts, unlike the Supreme Court's ruling impeachment, which is zero, obviously, for claims of privilege or for subpoenas or contempt, they do play a part. So he can absolutely string it out and I think that's a really powerful tool because at the end of it, it will be him and McGahn that shines rather than Congress with nothing to show for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. And Hillary Clinton who did not win the presidency --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Oh, really?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- she's written an op-ed --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Fox News alert.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She's written an op-ed in the Washington Post, I believe.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Have you read it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I skimmed it right before because it posted at about 4:55 PM. Basically, she's saying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Whoa, Greg got glasses on. Look at those things.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is my new glasses. I was waiting for somebody to notice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Professor Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, Professor Gutfeld. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's mesmerizing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very distracting, Dana. I know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Hillary Clinton basically says I know that I'm not necessarily the best messenger. Yes, I obviously lost and I think it is due to Russian interference. But, I also speak as a former senator and a former secretary of state, and Russian interference is a big problem. But she's saying that Congress should basically go as far as they can to fill in the gaps of the Mueller report. So that's the Hillary Clinton angle.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What gaps were there? I mean, I'm pondering myself what gaps there were. He was -- there, I think, two years and across $35 million, I think it was pretty exhaustive.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Bernie --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yes, to that -- what I thought what's interesting was how she closed it which basically said the most important part, the vital role is what the citizens played, and she used that to say -- so therefore, advocate for an impeachment proceedings rather than electorally which, as we all know how that happens and benefited her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what? This impeachment thing is only going to help Trump because it just -- he just seized all the media turf to him. And I think -- was it Sanders who recognized that first. He says like, we've got to start talking about our stuff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is just going to end -- Trump is going to eat this up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right. Well, again, wanting to do something is not a crime. And, by the way, there was no crime charged, so let's move on. Kamala Harris backtracking after being blasted for saying she considered letting convicted terrorists vote from prison. Big flip-flop up next.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Bernie Sanders igniting a firestorm for saying he'd let felons including terrorists vote from prison. And now, Kamala Harris is backtracking after appearing to agree with him.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: People who are convicted in prison, like the Boston marathon bomber, on death row, people who are convicted of sexual assault, they should be able to vote?

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: I think we should have that conversation. Do I think that people who commit murder, people who are terrorists should be deprived of their rights? Yeah, I do. I'm a prosecutor. I believe that in terms of their -- there has to be serious consequences for the most extreme type of crimes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: When you say that to the Boston bombers shouldn't be allowed to vote from prison, is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: I'm saying that I will weigh in specifically, but that's the value I bring to it, yeah.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: That Democratic idea is receiving widespread backlash, including from a firefighter who responded to the Boston marathon bombing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Society has rules and if you break those rules we have repercussion, and one of those repercussions is you lose your rights, one of them being the right to vote. Why would we ever let a murderer who murdered children, like the Boston marathon bomber, have a voice in our democracy?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Juan, I actually want to start with you. I want to know how you feel of the Democratic Party and that kind of progressive wave of it will respond to Kamala Harris backtracking and identifying herself as a prosecutor when up until now it seems like she's tried to distance herself from that aspect of her past, and really has been more of an advocate for, for example, the incarcerated.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think, in fact, it's an advantage for her to say that she is a former prosecutor. I mean, she went hard on drug crimes. I think there're a lot of people on the far left who say she went too far in terms of prosecuting people, for example breaking marijuana laws in the like in California. And tough -- and very tough prosecutor, in fact, in terms of the lot of youth crimes. But -- so I think that helps her in terms of her position as a Democratic moderate and someone who can be tough on crime, and it would be harder to position her as left-wing. In this specific debate it looks like she's backtracking though, doesn't it? And so, that's why I think getting all this attention. To be fair, Bernie Sanders put this out there and it has, I think, stirred a lot of conversation because, you know, I think it was Earl Warren, the chief justice, who said, you know, its citizenship is not a right to be revoked due to bad behavior. It's your rights. And I think Republicans in Florida and elsewhere, President Trump with his crime reform bill, everybody is saying we've got to do more in terms of rehabilitating people who've been in prison in order to cut down on recidivism.  We don't want people just churning and ending up being criminals again and back in jail and living off all of us, as we pay for the criminal justice system. So the question is how do we do it? I think this is an important conversation. I'm glad it started because I think that it's unfair to people who have been in jail and who've paid their dues to society to be denied their right to vote --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is not what the article -- this is not what this is about. This is about people who are currently in jail. Look, the reason when we have a dramatic decline in crime is because we incarcerate criminals. They lose their rights in jail. They do not go outside. They do not get to vote. Now, when they get out of jail, that's another story. Yes, but that's not what this is about. This is about what Bernie said, the Boston bomber should vote and could vote. I don't even know what you could add to that to make it worse. Oh, the Boston bomber should vote after he eats babies, maybe that would make it worse. But -- I'm kidding. She almost started crying there for a minute. So what I'm saying is Republicans don't need to exaggerate any of the planks of the Democrats. The Democrats are doing it for themselves, Juan. And you're a strong Democrat. You should be pulling them back and saying, you, guys, you're going nuts. Then you're going to reelect Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I see voter disenfranchisement too frequently in this country. But I must say --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm not talking about that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think that when you say, oh, (INAUDIBLE) brothers, or anybody, you know, should have their rights taken away. I'm saying, OK, so you're going to determine whose constitutional rights go on the toilet, and exactly where's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sure, why not.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're in jail for killing people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Look, I think we're -- as a society saying we understand that they are human beings that have citizenship rights.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And we took their rights away when they're in prison. They're not walking outside, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, now that they get out of jail, Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We're not talking about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Bernie was talking about being in jail. You're conflating it on purpose.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You are just focusing on that like --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- because you want to drive off the idea that Democrats --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I didn't say it. Bernie said it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah, Bernie --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Keep going with it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Personalize it. Someone in your family gets brutally assaulted, brutally assaulted, and you're going to say there in prison and they get to vote in the next election?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, Juan, you know you wouldn't feel good about that. You know that shouldn't happen. That's what you heard from survivors of the Boston bombing. They think this is atrocious.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Look, you know what? You can have all the emotions --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: As I've said, Greg and I went through this with Dukakis just yesterday, and Dukakis talking about his wife and the rape and all that. But I'm saying to you this is not about emotion. This is about your rights. In other words, if I say, you know what, Jesse did something I don't like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's not about that, Juan. It's about a society that's civilized because they don't want rapists and terrorists to be able to vote.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I see. And what's the constitution say?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Full stop. Full stop, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let me just say one more thing, Kamala Harris in two major instances where she was asked to really step up to the plate, completely whiffed. Remember after she launched that first week, she was asked about eliminating private health insurance companies. She goes in a flip way, yeah, get rid of them. And then in the other big moment she had on stage at CNN, she just said, oh, yeah, maybe the Boston bomber should vote. This shows she does not have sure political footing. It shows she lacks confidence and she has very poor instincts, and is not in touch with the American voting public.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Dana, how do you feel about that? How she permanently damage --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think she had a pretty good rollout in January, and that it's been a little bit lackluster. She has a structural advantage because she's from California and they have an early primary. But she still running third -- maybe fourth now in California, Biden, Bernie, and then her, and then may be Buttigieg right up there. And he actually has a fund-raiser coming up with Gwyneth Paltrow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's over. I've just learned that. Because she's been eclipsed by the 4 B's, Biden, Buttigieg, Bernie, and Beto, although --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Booker is not in the 4 B's.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's not in the 4 B's?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think that her candidacy is well sorted for the long haul, and she's got a lot of money. However, I would say this, conflating those two things won't work in a campaign ad. It might work here. Another thing, Bernie Sanders, once again, pushing the Democrats so far left that it will be very hard for them to be able to convince people. You have Mayor Pete, what was his instinct? No, OK? And we're not talking about the people who finish their jail time. For example, your freedom is taken away when you're put in jail. So your right to vote also, to me, that should be something that you want to get back. It should be the incentive for you to finish your sentence, pay your debt to society, maybe you're on good behavior you get early release, you leave, you get to vote again. But while you're in prison -- you killed people -- like, that is a weird conversation to have. And that Bernie Sanders has put them in that position again, I bet Joe Biden -- I mean, after he launches tomorrow, he gets asked about this, I know what he'll say.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know two states allow this, Maine and Vermont.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you realize that the conversation is just what you laid out, which is, in Florida and elsewhere, what happens to people once they get out --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God, .

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's the real conversation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. That's not what Bernie was saying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Bernie is interested in just that and you prefer the idea of making --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Rework the segment so it's about something you like.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: For the record, Jesse, I agree with you that Kamala has stumbled quite a bit in her campaign. And that reminds me, as a Californian, what we saw there is she worked her way up. She flip-flop quite a bit depending on who she was -- you know, law enforcement or not, or whatever --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: All right. Up next, Joe Biden getting ready to jump into the race, but Rush Limbaugh says he might want to think twice. See why, next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Welcome back. Joe Biden set to announce a presidential run tomorrow, but Rush Limbaugh says he's going to have a tough time in the crowded Democratic field.

utterances.speaker: RUSH LIMBAUGH, TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.sentences: Joe Biden is probably the best chance they've got, and he doesn't have a chance. They're probably -- Joe Biden, and crazy Bernie, and Mayor Pete? I mean, they get three white guys, two of them are brontosaurus from Jurassic Park, and that isn't going to sit well with the rest of this party which has gone so far left. I don't think -- you know, Biden is putting off this announcement. I don't know how badly he really wants this. And you have to really want this if you're going to have any chance of winning it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile, a confident President Trump mocking his Democratic challengers.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: They're not going to win with the people that I see. And they're not going to win against me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Emily, the president seems -- and Rush Limbaugh seems to say, oh, Democratic Party, so extreme, so far left, but the reason that Joe Biden is leading in the polls is that there so many Democratic voters who like him and seem to be supportive of him as a moderate Democrat.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: Correct, I think because of the name recognition he has at that point -- at this point, I mean. I do think that -- more than polls, I think the fund-raising will be a huge indicator of how actually that voting block feels about Biden. And when his campaign reports numbers, when the quarter two report comes out in July, we will find out whether those big- time donors that have thus far stayed out of it, whether they do, in fact, support him. And therefore, whether he's, frankly, in trouble or whether he has a long haul in front of him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse, part of the attractiveness of Biden in terms of Democratic voters is electability. Can you beat Trump? And you've heard Rush Limbaugh say, well, he's the best Democrat, that what he calls, though Limbaugh thinks they don't have a shot. So the reason that I think Limbaugh says that is Biden has a reputation as like a blue-collar white male, able to talk to people who might have Obama voters who switch to be Trump voters. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I agree, that's an asset that Biden has. But the critical thing that he needs to figure out is can I unify the base. Right now there's a crazy left-wing fringe extremist socialist part of the base that is dragging this party way over the cliff. And Biden has to be strong enough and crafty enough and articulate enough to say I'm Joe Biden, I'm electable, we had this great record under Barack Obama, and I know what I'm doing in Washington. But at the same time make the crazy people out there on the far left feel that he's one of them. And so far from what I've seen, I don't think he is skilled enough as a politician to be able to pull that off. So far he seems clumsy. The rollout is seemed awkward. The touchy-feelyness thing was weird. And he went on an apology tour. So from what I've seen so far, I just don't think he has the skills and the stomach actually because Limbaugh actually hit a good point. Does he really want it the way someone really wants it? And I just haven't seen it from him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Dana the thing that I think alarmed a lot of people inside the political game is that the video that's supposed to roll out tomorrow to announce that he's running apparently is being re-edited. They don't like it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh. Well never do that here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I wish we could.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We edit right up to the line. OK. I'm just going to give an alternative view. He has very high expectations for tomorrow. And whether that's fair or not, we'll see if he can meet them. I think the fund-raising point is a very good one, his appeal to them tomorrow to the Democrats, when he's in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania at the Union Hall is going to be, I can win this back. I can do this. And Democrats are actually quite rational. We talk about his touchiness. We talked about how he's out of touch. He still is the top of all the polls and Democrats and they're all far left, but although there is a lot of them, I also think that Bernie's numbers will start to go down once Biden gets in the race because he'll have somebody to quiet the crazy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what's interesting by the way on that point is that Bernie's numbers have gone down as Pete Buttigieg's numbers have gone--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: My man Mayor Pete with Gwyneth Paltrow, co-fundraiser.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't know if I believe that one. Bernie's numbers have been up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. Bernie's numbers have been coming down.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They've been coming down a little bit.

utterances.sentences: Ungrateful, I would say.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Ungrateful?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ungrateful.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, you're always tough on them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Kids today, Juan. Kids today.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wait till tomorrow, bring your kids to workday. Greg's favorite day of the year.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They're all taller than me.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.sentences: All right you guys, I want to draw your attention to the National Teacher of the Year, Rodney Robinson who here he works for the Richmond juvenile detention center. And I think that's absolutely amazing that he's dedicated his career to teaching not only these youth in detention but also committed to making them - make the most of their second chances essentially. And he teaches specifically social studies and history and he focuses on helping them become socially conscious citizens. And overall, he's really an amazing guy. Hats off.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Indeed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's wonderful.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Very nice. All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was Teacher of the Year once.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You were.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: For what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can't get into it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Neither will we. All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of “The Five.” "Special Report" is up next with Bret. utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Emily Compagno, Juan Williams, Dana Perino, and Greg. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is “The Five.” President Trump is ready for all-out war with investigation crazed Democrats on Capitol Hill.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: And I have been the most transparent president and administration in the history of our country by far. Now, the House goes and starts subpoenaing. They want to know every deal I've ever done. Now, Mueller, I assume, for $35 million, checked my taxes, checked my financials which are greats, but we're fighting all the subpoenas. Look, these aren't like impartial people. The Democrats are trying to win 2020, but they be should really focused on legislation. If you want to litigate, go after the DNC, crooked Hillary, the dirty cops.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Trump's fighting back against an avalanche of Democratic subpoenas including one calling for former White House Counsel Don McGahn to testify about the Mueller report. Trump's also saying that if Democrats do decide to impeach him he'll fight it all the way to the Supreme Court. Democrats responding by ramping up their rhetoric. Here's Nancy Pelosi.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: It's not about politics. It's about patriotism. It's an existential threat, this administration, to our democracy in terms of our constitution. I do believe that impeachment is one of the most divisive forces of paths that we could go down to our country, but if the facts -- the path of fact-finding takes us there, we have no choice. But we're not there yet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Maxine Waters who's been screaming about impeachment for two years is as unhinged as ever.

utterances.speaker: REP. MAXINE WATERS, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: I know that, as leaders, they have the responsibility to try and hold our caucus together. And to try and do and lead in the best way that they think will help us to be successful. If they believe that now was not the time for impeachment, they'll keep trying and they'll go down that road. We're going to have to impeach. I just wish it was sooner than later.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, we know what Maxine thinks, Greg. Nancy, I mean, she's the leader of the party in the House and she says that this administration is an existential threat to our democracy.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: That's crazy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What does that even mean?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a very overused term, existential. An existential threat, asteroids, cataclysmic climate change, Islamic terror, any time you're stuck in an elevator and Maroon 5 is playing, existential threat, but this is not. The suggestion that you are not a patriot if you somehow disagree with this idea, if you don't join in the resistance, we talked about this before, the expanding target of denigration, you are not a patriot. Let's go back to 2015, 2016. Having concerns about Trump made total sense, right? I had so many concerns. He wasn't a politician. His personality, he was a bull in a China shop. He never knew what he was going to do. He had an interesting, colorful past. And plus, you had all these other options. You have good options in the Republican Party. You had safer options. It didn't turn out that way but concerns made common sense. Now, people are having the same concerns three years later. None of their fears have materialized. The world -- he has not started any new wars. In fact, he has tried to shrink our military footprint. He has not destroyed the economy. We have a booming economy. We have the lowest unemployment in modern history. He's help minorities and women in that world. So when you see this kind of panic going on, all you can think about is it's OK if you're a Democrat. I get it. It's team sports. That's what you do. But if you actually believe this stuff, I would say like a never- Trump Republican, it's emotional and it's irrational. It's stupid. And that's all I've got to say.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, where do you think the Democrats stand right now on impeachment? It looks like they're pretty split, but no one can actually name the crime that they're impeaching him for. We're talking about broad things like a threat to democracy. That's not going to stick.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: That's not what we're talking about.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What are we talking about?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm alarmed that you don't realize that--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What is the crime?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- we're talking about obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But how did he do that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, gosh, he tried to tell Don McGahn --this is the point of great concern right now. He told McGahn to fire Mueller --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So he didn't Mueller.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No. McGahn, apparently, disobeyed his order. Now, Trump says nobody disobeyed his order, but we've seen --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wanting to fire someone which he has every right to do under article two. Wanting to fire someone is obstruction of justice?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, wanting to stop this investigation. This is something that I hear sometimes --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He ordered -- he calls up his lawyer, Don McGahn, and tells him to have the attorney general fire Mueller because of conflict of interest when there was no such thing going on, and McGahn saves him because it would have been an absolute fiasco.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But how is he obstructing?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, let me just say, I mean, even the Wall Street Journal this morning just said, you know, they believed McGahn. Now, Trump is saying McGahn is not telling the truth. They say, you know what, Trump lies just so much and it undermines his own credibility in so many ways. That's the Wall Street Journal conserve editorial page this morning. But let me just say there's so many instances like this. Greg says, oh, you know, things are going so great. Forget about normal Republican positions on things like lowering the deficit or not having all these trade tariffs or not undermining democracy --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How's the country going so far, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think that's going so well.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't have any evidence to counter.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You also say, Greg, oh, he's the most transparent president ever. If he's so transparent, why is he trying to stop Don McGahn from testifying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because enough is enough. He has given 1.4 million documents. Everyone has testified. He delivered written answered. Mueller looked at his taxes. There's nothing there. Why are the Democrats continuing to push this issue when they know that Mueller saw everything he needed to see?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All you can do is shout because he wouldn't even talk to Mueller. He did not testify for Mueller --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Written responses, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The point right now is that the Democrats are going to subpoena so much information -- I guess they could hold McGahn in, you know, contempt of Congress -- use to testify. But what the president and the White House are doing is basically slow walking it and saying, you know, we're stonewall, we'll slow walk, we'll end up in the courts, but we will not cooperate --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Emily, they've already cooperated fully. Mueller actually said that they have full cooperation. And right now, these two people, McGahn, Trump, special counsel, they're all under the executive branch. I mean, there's no reason they can't just claim executive privilege and say --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But they didn't claim it earlier.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They can claim it whenever they want.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, they can't.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Watch.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because he didn't say that -- when it was about McGahn testifying --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying it's obvious.

utterances.speaker: EMILY COMPAGNO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Here's what the president has on his side if he claims executive privilege for himself or McGahn moving forward, time and enforcement. What I mean by that is that subpoenas and orders of contempt are being held in contempt expires with that congressional duration, exactly. So all the president has to do is get to January of 2021. And also it is the courts, unlike the Supreme Court's ruling impeachment, which is zero, obviously, for claims of privilege or for subpoenas or contempt, they do play a part. So he can absolutely string it out and I think that's a really powerful tool because at the end of it, it will be him and McGahn that shines rather than Congress with nothing to show for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK. And Hillary Clinton who did not win the presidency --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Oh, really?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- she's written an op-ed --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Fox News alert.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She's written an op-ed in the Washington Post, I believe.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Have you read it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I skimmed it right before because it posted at about 4:55 PM. Basically, she's saying --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Whoa, Greg got glasses on. Look at those things.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is my new glasses. I was waiting for somebody to notice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Professor Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, Professor Gutfeld. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry. Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's mesmerizing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very distracting, Dana. I know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Hillary Clinton basically says I know that I'm not necessarily the best messenger. Yes, I obviously lost and I think it is due to Russian interference. But, I also speak as a former senator and a former secretary of state, and Russian interference is a big problem. But she's saying that Congress should basically go as far as they can to fill in the gaps of the Mueller report. So that's the Hillary Clinton angle.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What gaps were there? I mean, I'm pondering myself what gaps there were. He was -- there, I think, two years and across $35 million, I think it was pretty exhaustive.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bernie --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yes, to that -- what I thought what's interesting was how she closed it which basically said the most important part, the vital role is what the citizens played, and she used that to say -- so therefore, advocate for an impeachment proceedings rather than electorally which, as we all know how that happens and benefited her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? This impeachment thing is only going to help Trump because it just -- he just seized all the media turf to him. And I think -- was it Sanders who recognized that first. He says like, we've got to start talking about our stuff.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is just going to end -- Trump is going to eat this up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. Well, again, wanting to do something is not a crime. And, by the way, there was no crime charged, so let's move on. Kamala Harris backtracking after being blasted for saying she considered letting convicted terrorists vote from prison. Big flip-flop up next.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Bernie Sanders igniting a firestorm for saying he'd let felons including terrorists vote from prison. And now, Kamala Harris is backtracking after appearing to agree with him.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: People who are convicted in prison, like the Boston marathon bomber, on death row, people who are convicted of sexual assault, they should be able to vote?

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: I think we should have that conversation. Do I think that people who commit murder, people who are terrorists should be deprived of their rights? Yeah, I do. I'm a prosecutor. I believe that in terms of their -- there has to be serious consequences for the most extreme type of crimes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: When you say that to the Boston bombers shouldn't be allowed to vote from prison, is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.utterance: I'm saying that I will weigh in specifically, but that's the value I bring to it, yeah.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: That Democratic idea is receiving widespread backlash, including from a firefighter who responded to the Boston marathon bombing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Society has rules and if you break those rules we have repercussion, and one of those repercussions is you lose your rights, one of them being the right to vote. Why would we ever let a murderer who murdered children, like the Boston marathon bomber, have a voice in our democracy?

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Juan, I actually want to start with you. I want to know how you feel of the Democratic Party and that kind of progressive wave of it will respond to Kamala Harris backtracking and identifying herself as a prosecutor when up until now it seems like she's tried to distance herself from that aspect of her past, and really has been more of an advocate for, for example, the incarcerated.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think, in fact, it's an advantage for her to say that she is a former prosecutor. I mean, she went hard on drug crimes. I think there're a lot of people on the far left who say she went too far in terms of prosecuting people, for example breaking marijuana laws in the like in California. And tough -- and very tough prosecutor, in fact, in terms of the lot of youth crimes. But -- so I think that helps her in terms of her position as a Democratic moderate and someone who can be tough on crime, and it would be harder to position her as left-wing. In this specific debate it looks like she's backtracking though, doesn't it? And so, that's why I think getting all this attention. To be fair, Bernie Sanders put this out there and it has, I think, stirred a lot of conversation because, you know, I think it was Earl Warren, the chief justice, who said, you know, its citizenship is not a right to be revoked due to bad behavior. It's your rights. And I think Republicans in Florida and elsewhere, President Trump with his crime reform bill, everybody is saying we've got to do more in terms of rehabilitating people who've been in prison in order to cut down on recidivism. We don't want people just churning and ending up being criminals again and back in jail and living off all of us, as we pay for the criminal justice system. So the question is how do we do it? I think this is an important conversation. I'm glad it started because I think that it's unfair to people who have been in jail and who've paid their dues to society to be denied their right to vote --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is not what the article -- this is not what this is about. This is about people who are currently in jail. Look, the reason when we have a dramatic decline in crime is because we incarcerate criminals. They lose their rights in jail. They do not go outside. They do not get to vote. Now, when they get out of jail, that's another story. Yes, but that's not what this is about. This is about what Bernie said, the Boston bomber should vote and could vote. I don't even know what you could add to that to make it worse. Oh, the Boston bomber should vote after he eats babies, maybe that would make it worse. But -- I'm kidding. She almost started crying there for a minute. So what I'm saying is Republicans don't need to exaggerate any of the planks of the Democrats. The Democrats are doing it for themselves, Juan. And you're a strong Democrat. You should be pulling them back and saying, you, guys, you're going nuts. Then you're going to reelect Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I see voter disenfranchisement too frequently in this country. But I must say --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm not talking about that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think that when you say, oh, (INAUDIBLE) brothers, or anybody, you know, should have their rights taken away. I'm saying, OK, so you're going to determine whose constitutional rights go on the toilet, and exactly where's --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sure, why not.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're in jail for killing people.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Look, I think we're -- as a society saying we understand that they are human beings that have citizenship rights.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And we took their rights away when they're in prison. They're not walking outside, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, now that they get out of jail, Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We're not talking about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bernie was talking about being in jail. You're conflating it on purpose.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You are just focusing on that like --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- because you want to drive off the idea that Democrats --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't say it. Bernie said it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, Bernie --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Keep going with it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Personalize it. Someone in your family gets brutally assaulted, brutally assaulted, and you're going to say there in prison and they get to vote in the next election?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, Juan, you know you wouldn't feel good about that. You know that shouldn't happen. That's what you heard from survivors of the Boston bombing. They think this is atrocious.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Look, you know what? You can have all the emotions --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: As I've said, Greg and I went through this with Dukakis just yesterday, and Dukakis talking about his wife and the rape and all that. But I'm saying to you this is not about emotion. This is about your rights. In other words, if I say, you know what, Jesse did something I don't like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's not about that, Juan. It's about a society that's civilized because they don't want rapists and terrorists to be able to vote.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I see. And what's the constitution say?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Full stop. Full stop, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let me just say one more thing, Kamala Harris in two major instances where she was asked to really step up to the plate, completely whiffed. Remember after she launched that first week, she was asked about eliminating private health insurance companies. She goes in a flip way, yeah, get rid of them. And then in the other big moment she had on stage at CNN, she just said, oh, yeah, maybe the Boston bomber should vote. This shows she does not have sure political footing. It shows she lacks confidence and she has very poor instincts, and is not in touch with the American voting public.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Dana, how do you feel about that? How she permanently damage --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think she had a pretty good rollout in January, and that it's been a little bit lackluster. She has a structural advantage because she's from California and they have an early primary. But she still running third -- maybe fourth now in California, Biden, Bernie, and then her, and then may be Buttigieg right up there. And he actually has a fund-raiser coming up with Gwyneth Paltrow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's over. I've just learned that. Because she's been eclipsed by the 4 B's, Biden, Buttigieg, Bernie, and Beto, although --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Booker is not in the 4 B's.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's not in the 4 B's?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that her candidacy is well sorted for the long haul, and she's got a lot of money. However, I would say this, conflating those two things won't work in a campaign ad. It might work here. Another thing, Bernie Sanders, once again, pushing the Democrats so far left that it will be very hard for them to be able to convince people. You have Mayor Pete, what was his instinct? No, OK? And we're not talking about the people who finish their jail time. For example, your freedom is taken away when you're put in jail. So your right to vote also, to me, that should be something that you want to get back. It should be the incentive for you to finish your sentence, pay your debt to society, maybe you're on good behavior you get early release, you leave, you get to vote again. But while you're in prison -- you killed people -- like, that is a weird conversation to have. And that Bernie Sanders has put them in that position again, I bet Joe Biden -- I mean, after he launches tomorrow, he gets asked about this, I know what he'll say.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know two states allow this, Maine and Vermont.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And you realize that the conversation is just what you laid out, which is, in Florida and elsewhere, what happens to people once they get out --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God, .

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's the real conversation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. That's not what Bernie was saying.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Bernie is interested in just that and you prefer the idea of making --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Rework the segment so it's about something you like.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: For the record, Jesse, I agree with you that Kamala has stumbled quite a bit in her campaign. And that reminds me, as a Californian, what we saw there is she worked her way up. She flip-flop quite a bit depending on who she was -- you know, law enforcement or not, or whatever --

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: All right. Up next, Joe Biden getting ready to jump into the race, but Rush Limbaugh says he might want to think twice. See why, next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. Joe Biden set to announce a presidential run tomorrow, but Rush Limbaugh says he's going to have a tough time in the crowded Democratic field.

utterances.speaker: RUSH LIMBAUGH, TALK SHOW HOST
utterances.utterance: Joe Biden is probably the best chance they've got, and he doesn't have a chance. They're probably -- Joe Biden, and crazy Bernie, and Mayor Pete? I mean, they get three white guys, two of them are brontosaurus from Jurassic Park, and that isn't going to sit well with the rest of this party which has gone so far left. I don't think -- you know, Biden is putting off this announcement. I don't know how badly he really wants this. And you have to really want this if you're going to have any chance of winning it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, a confident President Trump mocking his Democratic challengers.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: They're not going to win with the people that I see. And they're not going to win against me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, Emily, the president seems -- and Rush Limbaugh seems to say, oh, Democratic Party, so extreme, so far left, but the reason that Joe Biden is leading in the polls is that there so many Democratic voters who like him and seem to be supportive of him as a moderate Democrat.

utterances.speaker: COMPAGNO
utterances.utterance: Correct, I think because of the name recognition he has at that point -- at this point, I mean. I do think that -- more than polls, I think the fund-raising will be a huge indicator of how actually that voting block feels about Biden. And when his campaign reports numbers, when the quarter two report comes out in July, we will find out whether those big- time donors that have thus far stayed out of it, whether they do, in fact, support him. And therefore, whether he's, frankly, in trouble or whether he has a long haul in front of him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse, part of the attractiveness of Biden in terms of Democratic voters is electability. Can you beat Trump? And you've heard Rush Limbaugh say, well, he's the best Democrat, that what he calls, though Limbaugh thinks they don't have a shot. So the reason that I think Limbaugh says that is Biden has a reputation as like a blue-collar white male, able to talk to people who might have Obama voters who switch to be Trump voters. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I agree, that's an asset that Biden has. But the critical thing that he needs to figure out is can I unify the base. Right now there's a crazy left-wing fringe extremist socialist part of the base that is dragging this party way over the cliff. And Biden has to be strong enough and crafty enough and articulate enough to say I'm Joe Biden, I'm electable, we had this great record under Barack Obama, and I know what I'm doing in Washington. But at the same time make the crazy people out there on the far left feel that he's one of them. And so far from what I've seen, I don't think he is skilled enough as a politician to be able to pull that off. So far he seems clumsy. The rollout is seemed awkward.
